STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 4, 2023
Darnell Thomas Britt
Community Care Organization
18688 Joann St,
Detroit, MI, 48205-2748
RE: License#: CB820315857
Dear Darnell Thomas Britt:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 11/30/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Group Organization: Community Care Organization
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington
Chief Administrator: Darnell Thomas Britt
Name of Agency: Community Care Organization
Agency Address: 18688 Joann St.
Detroit MI 48205-2748
Agency Telephone #: 3133344750
Original Issuance Date: 07/30/2013
License Effective Date 1/30/2022
License Expiration Date 1/29/2024
Service Types: Supervise Independent Living

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
One of three new employee records reviewed, where the employee had lived out
of state in 2018, did not show documentation of an out-of-state central registry
clearance from that state.
Repeat Violation cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 3/22/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or

her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of three new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of a
six month performance evaluation, which was due by 9/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law.
An agency shall comply with the child protection law,
1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Of the three new employee records reviewed and the four employee records
reviewed where the employee was employed over one year, the records did not
show documentation of a central registry clearance and CPS History Review via
the division of child welfare licensing (DCWL) as required by the rule. The
agency reported confusion related to being required to complete this task for
these employees.
The agency was advised to request these clearances for all its employee as soon
as possible.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.
One of four open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of initial financial support to meet the youth's housing, clothing,
food and miscellaneous expenses.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient
to meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and
miscellaneous expenses.

One of four independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of current financial support to meet the youth's housing, clothing,
food and miscellaneous expenses.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with the
youth's biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.
Two of four open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the youth's 7-25-2023-10/22/23 updated service plan
(USP) was completed four days late.
• A second record showed the youth's 5/17/2023-8/14/2023 USP was
completed two days late.
Repeat Violation cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 3/22/2023; and the December 2021 Renewal inspection,
with a CAP approved on 1/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of four open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of a March, June or September 2023 contract between the agency
and the youth.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the

following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(b) The youth's new location.
Three of four closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of(b) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Four of four closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of(c) and (d) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violations cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 3/22/2023; and the December 2021 Renewal inspection,
with a CAP approved on 1/18/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12504(2(f) Eligibility requirements & R400.12509(3)(g) Independent
living record.
• The agency was apprised the initial and quarterly budgets it conducts
with youths to show verification of initial and current proof of financial
support to meet the youth's needs must always be verifiable.
R400.1509(3)(o) Independent living record.
• The agency was apprised the education information sections within the
youths updated service plan shall be consistently updated.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12503 Policy and procedures.
• The agency was given consultation on various policies it has updated.
Notably, regarding its policies related to the child protection law,

medical care, and youth stipends. The agency was advised that more
detail is needed on all. As well as more specifics are required as to
what is a fair assessment of what number of missed life skill courses,
curfew violations and missed chores would illustrate the youth is not
actually participating in the program, so as to aid in defining what
“actively involved” in the program entails.
R400.12504(2(f) Eligibility requirements & R400.1509(3)(g)
• The agency was advised consistent sign-off of the budget by the youth
and workers can aid in showing clear documentation of the rule.
R400.12510 Independent living contract.
• The agency was given consultation on how to ensure that the
independent living agreement it uses with youths clearly shows the
youths location, and all aspects as required by the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
This incident related to Special Investigation 2023C0000372 intiated on 4/6/2023.
The complaint alleged that a staff person pushed a youth down some stairs. The
investigation determined that the two staff involved in the incident had escalated the
program youths and had demonstrated an inability to perform their duties as required
by the rule. The MDHHS Worker also had findings related to the incident. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective plan on 8/1/2023; and the two staff
involved in the incident were terminated prior to that.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during this
licensing period.
The first corrective plan related to the agency’s January 2023 Interim inspection,
where the agency received the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(2)(b) Personnel records.
• R400.12212(2)(h) Personnel records.
• R 400.12509(3)(o) Independent living record.
• R400.12511(1)(c)-(d) Termination.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
The agency made some progress on its Interim Inspection corrective action plan,
but it was not totally successful with all areas of the corrective action plan as
indicated by the repeat violations in this Interim Inspection report.
The agency's second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2023C0000372 initiated on 4/6/2023, as referenced earlier in this report. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective plan on 8/1/2023. The corrective
action plan indicated a meeting was held with the staff involved in the incident on
3/12/2023 whereby the agency’s Staff Emergency procedures were reviewed with
those staff. Additionally, staff would receive de-escalation, and non-violent crisis
intervention training on 8/12/2023, and new staff would receive this training after
hire. The two staff involved in this incident were terminated effective 5/11/2023.
Documentation of staff training on 8/12/2023 was seen during this Renewal
Inspection. This corrective action plan was completed.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/3/2023. I provided
the chief administrator consultation related to the annual assessment and
disrupted and unplanned removal sections of this report. That more detail is
required for the assessment area of this report and an actual number of
disruptions is required. Otherwise, there were no noted concerns related to this
report.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of their 9/30/2022 independent financial audit, and
projected annual budget. No concerns were indicated.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to my discussion with the licensee designee and communication with
the chief administrator, I interviewed one independent living foster care worker,
and one youth advocate. Both staff are senior employees with the agency and no
concerns were reported.

Three youths were interviewed for this inspection. No areas of concern were
indicated. All three youths indicated their case worker visits them regularly and
helps them.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A review of the agency's office did not show any areas of concern.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Not applicable. This is an independent living program.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
December 4, 2023
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 5, 2023
_____________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
